body.p:
I have to acknowledge the receipt of your
esteem'd letter with the enclosed sheets of your intended Bible.
I like it very much & wish you much success: but wishing without
acting will not tend furthering your views. I havegiven them to my
friend Em. Mocatta—who has kindly promised to shew them to his
friends in London. Will you please to put my name down for a copy—
Mrs. L. H. Samuel. one copy—Mr. Sylvester L. Samuel—one copy
I have & shall speak of it whenever opportunity offers. I
perfectly agree with you that a proper translation of our holy
Bible ought and should be had for our Youth in order that they
might not be led astray from the bias which the old translators had
in the olden time—probably when you have completed your great work
a cheap edition for the use of schools would be productive of in-
calcuable good and greatly promotive of our Holy faith * Your Ideas
of offerings & Blessings (for money) in our Synagogues meet with my
entire approbation. I believe I was the first in Liverpool to
strike a blow at the System & I have invariably declined offering
for some years past. I have not the least objection to contribute
my full share for the support of its officers by an assessment. & in
answer to those opposed to my views & will not contribute by by a
public display of their charity I will give them such display: if
they will send their donations. I will publish them in print every
year and circulate them not only in our immediate community but through
the world in our yearly account current as the donation of Mr. So & So.
first donation—Second do—third do—& so on so that all may know
their munificence: But no mention of Mammon in the House of God.

I can't stand to hear a worthless irreligious Bad man called to the
Sefer and crave from the Almighty a blessing for me for which he
offers—12 Cents!! (or 6 pence). I won't have it & please God
shall do all in my power to abolish the system.
Wishing you a Happy New Year,
Please to put my name down for two copies of Dias' Letters
